title: (x) Be Gluebalized - Heineken custom logo font {David Hubner}
content:
looks like an easy ones - but i can't find it. can somebody id this slab serif?   
   
 ![](http://web.archive.org/web/20081206110022im_/http:/www.typophile.com/forums/messages/83/17989.jpg)

 [‹ 't Keramieksken](http://web.archive.org/web/20081206110022/http:/www.typophile.com/node/1541 "Go to previous forum topic") [(x) Campbell's Soup - hand lettering {Eduardo, Daniel Weaver} ›](http://web.archive.org/web/20081206110022/http:/www.typophile.com/node/1535 "Go to next forum topic")
author: nike

comments.content:
Damn! Not in the FontBook, nor in Rookledge's...   
It looks like a 70s New York advertising face.

yves: what is rookledge's? any mysterious fast-access book you use to retain your "fastest font-identer" role? ![:-)](http://web.archive.org/web/20081206110022im_/http:/www.typophile.com/forums/clipart/happy.gif) lars

yves, it must be a digital typeface.   
 [http://www.mimic.it/new/](http://web.archive.org/web/20081206110022/http:/www.mimic.it/new/)   
   
my first tought was, that I'll find it in a few minutes. it seems to be a brain teaser.

Hmm, looks just like the Heineken Logotype..   
Maybe its a custom Typeface.?   
   
 [www.heineken.com](http://web.archive.org/web/20081206110022/http:/www.heineken.com/) | [www.logo.nino.ru/main/?text=heineken](http://web.archive.org/web/20081206110022/http:/logo.nino.ru/main/?text=heineken&x=0&y=0&id=135)

..But, there is a ( Shamrocking ) Freefont, named 'Heineken', out there..   
Maybe thats the one that has been used..   
   
 [www.shamrocking.com/fonts.html](http://web.archive.org/web/20081206110022/http:/www.shamrocking.com/fonts.html)   
( Fonts / Free / Heineken.. )

david, nice catch. it seems to be the heineken font.   
   
btw.   
schade, dass du deine site aufgegeben hast. ich fand sie sehr gelungen. vor allem deine arbeiten.

I still believe that the original Heineken Typeface is a custom one..

\*\*

Lars, That was my [exact question](http://web.archive.org/web/20081206110022/http:/www.typophile.com/forums/messages/83/4501.html) when I first heard about this mysterious Rookledge.   
   
It's like the type-IDers secret handshake.

well, about rooklegde:   
   
 [http://www.amazon.com/exec/obidos/tg/detail/-/1559210524?v=glance](http://web.archive.org/web/20081206110022/http:/www.amazon.com/exec/obidos/tg/detail/-/1559210524?v=glance)   
   
strange thing is, that they also do a "Architectural Identifier of Conservation Areas":   
   
 [http://www.amazon.co.uk/exec/obidos/ASIN/1870758056/ref=br\_lf\_b\_19/](http://web.archive.org/web/20081206110022/http:/www.amazon.co.uk/exec/obidos/ASIN/1870758056/ref=br_lf_b_19/)   
   
 ![:-)](http://web.archive.org/web/20081206110022im_/http:/www.typophile.com/forums/clipart/happy.gif) lars

Hi Lars, sorry that I didn't get back to you about   
Rookledge's International Type Finder, but I have   
been (a) very busy and (b) without e-mail notification   
the past few days. I see you've found the information   
yourself and Karen has been so kind to direct you to   
the previous thread where it got mentionned and   
explained (THX Karen).   
Now that e-mail notification seems to be working   
again I hope I'll get back to normal speed.

David brilliant ID BTW. I guess that's why it seemed   
so familiar to most of us but we still weren't able to   
find it. It's a bit like recognizing someone out of his/   
her normal context: you recognize the person but   
can't pinpoint where from.
